answers.answer: Dear Slipping Away,Your letter is concerning.  Don't let your family's biases stop you from getting the help you need.Your symptoms are suggestive of depression. Effective treatment is available.If you are unable to see a psychiatrist, go to to your family doctor, or if you are feeling that you want to end your life, go to the nearest emergency room.Best Wishes,HFHS M.D.-SW

I am sorry you are having a hard time and that you do not have anyone that supports you.Often, people do not understand that a person cannot help depression any more than they can help having diabetes.  Sometimes it is a chemical imbalance.I hope you will seek out the help  you need regardless of what someone else might think.  You must think of yourself first in this situation.  Depression is miserable for you and you will not be able to give your children what they need either.I suffered many years with depression before I was put on medication.  I am doing so well that I wish the best for you, too.Go get help!

question: How do I go about getting help for myself when my husband, parents, all look down on people with mental problems? I know that I need help desparately considering I am constantly thinking of ways to end my life and have become a prisoner in my basement so much as to become vitamin D deficient. There is no way that I could even suggest to them that I might need help. So in the meantime, I just withdrawal more and more and feel so guilty about it when my children ask me why I don't spend time with them anymore.
title: How To Go About Seeking Help
